Award.AwardTitle: Alaskan Athabascan Grammar Database Development: Koyukon (koy), Lower Tanana (taa), and Upper Tanana (tau)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers intend to develop a database organizing sentence data from three highly endangered Alaskan Athabascan languages: Koyukon, Lower Tanana, and Upper Tanana. Much of the data is already available in published and manuscript dictionaries, or in texts and language learning materials, but it is not currently accessible to researchers and language teachers in readily comparable form. Additional data will be collected as part of this project to fill gaps and to enrich and clarify what has been previously archived.

The database will organize the data from two perspectives: form-to-function and function-to-form. In selecting the constructions/forms to be included, we will consult a number of grammars of other Athabascan languages such as Rice (1989) and de Reuse and Goode (2006). In the selection of functions to be included, we will use extant tools such as the World Atlas on Language Structures (Dryer & Haspelmath 2011) and the GOLD ontology (Farrar & Langedoen 2003) to build our categories. Examples of search terms on the formal side are independent pronouns, classifiers, interrogative particles, or extra-high tone (to name but a few); on the functional side commands (both positive and negative), questions, topicalization, and many more.

Searching by form will be useful to researchers familiar with Athabascan languages; searching by function to researchers interested in typological questions. Additionally, this tool will be a helpful resource for Athabascan language learners and educators, who need references for curriculum development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed an online database that allows users to search for language examples in three highly endangered Native languages of Alaska, Koyukon, Lower Tanana and Upper Tanana. Previously there has been no structured system for learners and teachers of these languages to find examples that match their needs for personal learning or class planning. With this website, designed by two Athabascan language specialists and a computational linguist, it is now possible to learn with a few clicks how to do things (how to ask questions, issue commands, tell what happened or what should happen, for example) in each of these languages.

Language examples from many sources have been imported to the database, including examples from dictionaries, lessons and stories that have been preserved at the Alaska Native Language Archive at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Many new examples have been collected during the project, and speakers of the three languages have helped to annotate each example for sentence structure, word structure and appropriate usage. 

The database is easily expandable to include other languages, within and outside of the Athabascan language family. 

The Alaskan Athabascan Grammar Database project is part of a movement in linguistics that dedicates time and effort to the support and revitalization of endangered languages. These efforts contribute to society in many ways beyond their academic value. On the local level, individuals and families in endangered language communities receive validation for their own struggles to maintain their heritage. Young learners are inspired to study, both in the academy and in home environments. When a funded study allows linguists and technology experts to collaborate on new tools specifically designed to attend to these languages, prestige is heightened and the community benefits.  

On a larger scale and a longer timeline, this project provides an annotated record of language knowledge, designed so that its usefulness can be expanded to different audiences.
